section: Notwithstanding paragraphs 4A, 4B and 4C above, CONSULTANT shall be entitled to endorse and play the [*****]. The parties expressly agree that CONSULTANT may permit [*****] the use of CONSULTANT'S name and/or likeness in [*****] print and/or television advertisement provided that this is executed in a manner consistent with [*****] past [*****] advertising practice using similarly situated professional golfers with competing golf club endorsement agreements that include [*****]. If [*****] use of CONSULTANT varies from past practice of utilizing similarly situated professionals, CONSULTANT will take action to remedy the situation [*****]. If CONSULTANT participates directly in any [*****] sponsored photo shoots for advertising or PR, CONSULTANT shall wear his ADAMS GOLF [*****]. The parties further expressly agree that CONSULTANT'S endorsement of the [*****] shall not include the right to place a [*****] logo on his ADAMS GOLF [*****] or the ADAMS GOLF [*****]. If CONSULTANT'S relationship with [*****] terminates during this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall be permitted to replace the [*****] endorsement with another [*****] endorsement under the same terms and conditions expressed herein.
explanation: This section creates ambiguity and potential contradictions due to the extensive redactions. While it attempts to create exceptions to the exclusivity clauses in 4A, 4B, and 4C, the redactions make it impossible to fully understand the scope and limitations of these exceptions. Specifically, it's unclear what specific product or entity the consultant is allowed to endorse. This is compounded by the references to 'past practice' without defining what constitutes past practice. The sentence about remedy is also vauge as there is no further explaination of how to remedy the situation.

section: A. During the term of this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall use best efforts to be available for such press interviews, radio or TV appearances arranged for CONSULTANT by ADAMS GOLF which are compatible with CONSULTANT'S own practice, play and personal time requirements. CONSULTANT will be required to be available after a tournament for selected interviews, either the Sunday afternoon or Monday morning following the tournament. In all such interviews and appearances, CONSULTANT will use his best efforts to make reference to the ADAMS GOLF PRODUCT and wear [*****] and display ADAMS GOLF'S brand name.
explanation: This section presents a contradiction between the 'best efforts' clause and the 'required to be available' clause. While the first sentence indicates CONSULTANT needs to use best efforts to be available, the second sentence states that the consultant 'will be required' to be available after a tournament for selected interviews. This suggests that it is no longer best efforts and that the consultant is obligated to be present. It is also unclear what is meant by the word selected interviews.

section: Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, if either party commits any material breach of this Agreement, the other party may terminate for cause upon giving fifteen (15) days written notice of such cause and provided the breach is not rectified within such fifteen (15) day period. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: The contradiction lies in the 'material breach' clause and the repayment requirement upon termination for cause. The repayment clause, referencing paragraph 8A, seems geared towards situations where the CONSULTANT fails to meet minimum performance standards (number of tournaments played). Applying this repayment scheme to a 'material breach' by either party (which could encompass various violations beyond tournament participation) creates an inequitable outcome. For instance, if Adams Golf materially breaches the contract (e.g., fails to make payments), and the Consultant terminates, it seems illogical and punitive to require the Consultant to repay any portion of the compensation. Conversely, if the Consultant commits a severe breach, calculating repayment based solely on time elapsed might not adequately compensate Adams Golf for the damages caused by the breach. Thus, the application of the 8A repayment calculation to all terminations for cause creates a misaligned and potentially unfair remedy.
